reviewText: Alright, let's put aside the hate and generalized distaste for this game and actually break it down into something that may be worth your time. Now, to start out, I would like to say that I pre-ordered this game the day I heard about it and the day the developers released a video on  the vaulting mechanics. I played the crap out of this game for a while and I didn't care what other people thought (partly because I didn't know people hated it until long after I defeated the game and unlocked all of the guns, outfits, and most of the skills/attachments). Truly, this game is a lot of fun. Think of this game as a really watered down version of TF2 with classes such as the Engineer or Operator (hacker, etc.) that can be switched around with others on the fly. The gun play may not be the best but it really is fun when you start leveling your character and unlocking stuff. Attachments help a lot and skills do as well such as having third person when interacting with the objectives in-game. -(Note that I am writing this review years after I stopped playing)-.\nThe story is something that I felt like was just a filler for the story missions, in the beginning, but as you progress that slowly changes. Throughout the game you can find dialogues and journal entries that really add to the game's back-story and adds some real character that would have been otherwise unkown in-game. The end mission is really intense and a lot of fun whether or not you win or not. The game sets itself up for a sequel, but it looks like it may never happen in the near future. Truly, this game had a lot of heart and some pretty good art-design with some great back-story that would have made this game a real hit. Game mechanic choices and poor decisions really watered this game down to the point where no one likes it but the selective few like myself. In reality, I am writing this review out of nostalgia out of the lots of fun I had with this game. Pick it up if you would like sometime soon, fairly small and can be run pretty easily with any system. I would suggest getting it on sale because it may not be worth the full price.\nThank you for your time and have a wonderful day.

reviewText: This is probably one of the most underrated games of the 21st century. I picked it up back on the PS3 originally, and despite it's flaws at launch such as mediocre AI and minor lag, (issues that were improved later into the games life) it was an absolute blast to play. The varying levels of customization were great, spanning all the way from weapons to the character itself. Not only that, but all the maps played well and looked absoulutely georgeous. The gameplay was a refreshing change to what you experienced in most FPS games at the time, with fun and flamboyant free running moves that not only looked great but were simple to execute. However, because Brink was developed by 'Splash Damage' and not 'Infinity Ward' websites such as IGN and Gamespot gave it a 6, slamming the game for it's poor AI and repetition. Sure I'd accept that if this was a game that based itself around singleplayer rather than multiplayer gameplay, but marking it down for repetition when video games such as Modern Warfare 2 get given 9's is ridiculous.\n\nAt the end of the day, this was a game that had it's head put on the block before it even got released. Sure, it's far from perfect, but it's as good as your going to get if your looking for a multiplayer FPS that's a little different from the norm.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic.  Did I expect it to have a call of duty-style campaign? No because I'm not an idiot.  I know that isn't what was shown in trailers and that Splash Damage (the developers) were obviously making a 3rd Enemy Territory game.  It's also fantastic that this game has GOOD BOTS since I always play the games I want instead of whatever anyone else is playing.  Servers don't matter, good gameplay does, and this has it.  I knew what I was getting when I got BRINK and I wasn't disappointed in the slightest.

I remember dreaming of putting call of duty 4's shooting into TF2 as well as wishing that Mirror's Edge-style parkour could be added to many more first-person games.  BRINK made that dream come true and it has been everything I hoped it would be since I bought it on launch for the PS3 so long ago.  Unfortunate things happened to my PS3 and that version of BRINK.  So glad to have it back on steam now.

When BRINK came out, the gameplay was focused on solving common problems in FPS games at the time.  It competely succeeded.  For example, grenades can't be spammed randomly to get easy kills, they do lighter damage and knock the target over.  The weapons as well were well-balanced from launch and no gun was obviously dominante like happened in so many shooters and still does.  As for game structure, they use Enemy Territory's fantastic assault-style game mode wherein you accomplish one objective after another.  One team attacks, one team defends in a dichotomy that I prefer over any other game mode.  A feeling of progress, unique perspective for each team, and varied objectives are why this is my favorite game mode.  If only more competitve shooters used this mode (I call it Assault" mode because of my experience with the original Unreal Tournament)

reviewText:
“Brink takes shooters to a whole new level.”
-G4TV

“Brink impresses from pretty much every angle.”
-Eurogamer

“..one of the standout shooters of the year.”
-Destructoid

Liars, the lot of you!

Now that that’s out of my system, I want to thank Brink. It corrected a poor habit of mine while it was still in its infancy.  That habit was blind publisher loyalty.  When I first came across Brink, I wanted to like it.  I really did.  I was immediately interested in its art style, and the Bethesda logo in the corner of the box assured me of its unquestionable quality.  How wrong I was, and how very much I overpaid that day, I cannot stress enough.

As a competitive first-person shooter, Brink has a lot of competition on today’s market, and yet it just feels like the developers haven’t picked one up in the last ten years.  Case in point: Brink sports no campaign to speak of.  The single-player mode, guided by a sheer-thin veneer of a narrative, is just a string of multiplayer maps in which players’ squadmates are A.I.s with about as much tactical sense as a rabid honey badger.   Multiplayer itself is stiflingly limited in terms of map variety, arena size, and weapon options, and many of the maps are rife with arbitrary choke-points that fatally cut down on the pace and entertainment value of gameplay.

Avatar and weapon customization is a welcome feature, and the options available do allow for some unique and inventive character designs, but the decision to require unlocks and temporary in-game purchases for rather basic customization options, like body types, smacks as a bit counter-productive to players finding their niche early on. The total lack of female avatar options at all is equally disappointing.  There are female gamers out there, Splash Damage, and they don’t always want a mountain of armored flesh for an avatar.

Perhaps most disappointing of all, the parkour elements that seem to have been such an integral part of the game’s concept are clunky at best, and a tacked-on gimmick the rest of the time.  Mirror’s Edge this ain’t, as it’s often difficult to tell which surfaces a player can vault over, which ledges one can grab onto, and why one shouldn’t just take cover and use some tactical sense rather than running into the open to charge enemies armed with assault rifles and shotguns.  There’s just no incentive the put it to use the vast majority of the time.

Wrapping up, Brink is visually pretty average.  Personally, I found its art style to be quite inspired and rather reminiscent of the modernistic, tagger-culture influenced, Marc Ecko’s getting up, but that’s just my personal taste, and will not factor into the game’s rating. The score and sound effects are par for the course, but ultimately forgettable, and its mechanics just fall short of their intended mark.  Most damning of all is the fact that there are now multiple free-to-play shooters on the market that outclass Brink in every way.  Blacklight:Retribution, Team Fortress 2, and APB Reloaded, just to name a few, are all superior titles that come with a zero dollar price tag, casting Brink’s sixty-dollar launch-mark in a pretty grim light.

reviewText:
2011 was a game of big releases, we can all agree on that...Skyrim, Arkham City, Fallout New Vegas DLC's, Portal 2, MW3, Battlefield 3, Gears of War 3, Serious Sam 3, FEAR 3, something that ends with a 3, etc.

But no other game, NO OTHER! Got my attention as much as BRINK, BRINK had my highest expectations of 2011, more than skyrim, Arkham City, Portal 2 or any other game.
Did it meet the hype? Sadly, no...maybe I hyped it too much, but many people have the same feeling as me.
Starting with the graphics, they are not groundbreaking, but not bad either, ok-ish I would say, however it has pretty slow texture pop-ins...
The game also feels to be poorly optimized and console ported (you can't lower teh shadows more than normal, and besides that there aren't all that many options besides texture quality and V-Sync. So, if you have a crappy computer, you're screwed!).
Moving to the gameplay, it's what somewhat saves the game, your character flows really nicely thanks to SMART (Smooth Movement Across Round Terrain, I think it stands for...) and teamwork is a very important aspect focused in this game, so there wont be any Lone Wolf crap here (I mean there can be if a noob enters, but he will get totally owned...). Sadly, the guns lack punch, only some assault rifles and shotguns and pistols, SMG's feel terrible and they have like a F2P-like handling (watermelon seed shooter).
A good thing about the game is the customization: It's enormous, absolutely HUGE! It's impossible for 2 people to have 2 characters look the same. It's very deep! Both the character and weapon customization.
The game also features a class based system, assault, medic, etc. There is even the secret ops guy or whatever the name is (which is like the spy from TF2, can sap and hack stuff and disguise as an enemy. Except BRINK, unlike TF2, requires skill...). It's varied and VERY interesting.
Audio quality is pretty good, surprisingly (not the guns, btw), your movement, jumping, the effect sounds, etc. All are really well done.
Map layout and level design is absolutely phenomenal! It has many twists and encourages tactics, like ascend to higher places or flanking, as it's very team and objective focused!

The word of the day for BRINK is definately: Potential! Potential! Potential!
Sadly it's just the potential. If Bethesda gets their thumbs off their asses and stop supporting Skyrim and start growing balls and investing in BRINK, I would be very pleased, but more careful, after all, I paid 50 euros for this game to get 80 minutes out of it. -.-
But before BRINK 2 or something along those lines, I'm still waiting for FALLOUT 4! HUH?! Oh sorry Bethesda, I forgot it's your money-bath time...

Anyways, I wont give a score. get under 9,99€ anything equal or under that is worth it! Beware, this game isn't bad! It's a colossal disappointment, it's different. If the expectation were much lower, this game would be GOOD! But all that hype not met...it's disappointing and it saddens me. A lot...

reviewText:
Never usually write reviews but felt i had to because of all the hate this game gets. Originally bought it for Xbox 360 and LOVED it so bought it again for PC.
Pros:
Some of the best character design I’ve seen in my life, the games art direction is impeccable and so it looks stunning. The character customization is probably the best in an fps game I’ve ever seen with so many awesome different helmets, tattoos etc. (You can even decide your characters voice!) Overall the visuals and aesthetics of this game are near perfect. Intriguing story sets up game nicely and gives it a unique feel although they could have gone more in depth. There are two campaigns from both sides of the conflict and also what if scenario missions so a decent amount of single player content. Shooting mechanics are basic but there is a nice variation in classes and absolutely awesome parkour mechanics.
Cons:
No one online so the multiplayer is pretty dead, sometimes the AI in single player can be a little dumb but only occasionally. Apart from the story missions there isn't much else to do apart from some challenges (however they do have leader boards).

Conclusion:
One of my favourite games of all time, I can’t understand why it gates so many bad reviews, with some tweaks to the AI more content and a living multiplayer base this game would be PERFECT.

reviewText:
There is something about brink, the atmosphere, the soundtrack, the look of the world your in.

If you have ever stared off into the distance in mirrors edge, you will understand the beauty of this game.

The contrast between the resistance and the security’s living areas is crafted perfectly to give you a true sense of the poverty the resistance is fighting to overcome and the wealth the security is trying to protect.

Brink feels like its own separate world where you can immerse yourself in either saving or ending the ARK.

If you take this game seriously, it will reward you with two great sides to a story and two very different viewpoints on the way money can influence your views.

I found it best to play the game alone, against bots (single player mode) to give the best immersion possible.

reviewText:
Good mix of sp and mp game. Good audio-visuals. Nice (rather small/medium) maps. Great movement mechanics -
very fluid. Various body types allow different weapons and different level of movement freedom (light - very fast and able to climb, medium - fast, but not that agile, thick - bullet sponge+turtle movement+no vertical advantage). Two factions offer different stories. Guns are ok and so are the perks. Classess are standard - engineer, assault, spy and
medic. Customization of your character and weapons is pretty rich. Solo game allows bots, so you don't run
all by yourself when people don't join. Game is objective based - there is no standard DM/TDM/CTF. I would say that it has potential, but something didn't click. It is still enjoyable even with bots - they tend to do well (not perfect but enough to win all maps and finish the story).  I still play it at times - a map or two. Fun thing.

Performance on this is weird. It doesn't need powerful PC (I'd say weak on will do), but I faced sudden crashes on 2 of my machines (one under Win XP SP3 and Win 7 x64 Ultimate SP1 and laptop with Win 8.1 x64). Graphics is ok, nothing extreme in any direction. It has a touch of cartoon/cel shading. Sound is good (voice, guns, ambience). Controls are fine and the port seems solid (just those sudden crashes on different machines).

reviewText:
Brink is all about running around with your team trying to achieve a number of set objectives, which usually involves killing an enemy team on the way.
I have a fairly large number of criticisms of this game, the first of which is that there are loads of customisations, yet no female characters. AI isn’t too bad, but the bots on your team are constantly getting in the way. Game-play is very confusing. Not only are the objectives very unclear, but enemies seem to just appear in the worst possible places. You are often staggering  around lost and confused, then you get incapped without knowing where the bullet even came from becaseu an enemy spawned behind you. And enemies seem to be far more difficult to kill than you are! All in all it adds up to a lot of frustration.
It’s not a bad game, but it's far from a great game. It has some serious game-play issues. Recommended? Well, At at Sale price, yes, but not at full price.

reviewText:
I've previously owned this game before on PS3, so I decided to give the game another chance on PC.

Personally, I like the artstyle, its fairly unique and sets the game apart from other run of the mill shooters. Although it is what you'd expect, everything for the resistance is improvised and gritty, everything for the security forces is shiny, white and looks brand new, etc. The soundtrack is also decent, the main menu theme is currently stuck in my head as I write this review.

The gameplay is class based, the game requires a large degree of teamwork to accomplish any of the objectives, this isn't really a game where you can be the lone wolf and decimate everything in your path. Anyone familiar with games such as TF2 or star wars battlefront, will feel right at home with the gameplay. The only aspect of the gameplay I don't like is the parkour, its very jerky, sometimes unresponsive, and difficult to pull off in certain situations due to the 1st person view limiting your perspective of the surrounding environment, it feels like the parkour was an afterthought and was wedged in at the last minute in order to attract the Mirrors Edge crowd. However, I've found that parkour isn't particularly usefull in all the missions anyway, so the clunkyness isn't really a problem as I rarely used parkour to its full extent.

Character customisation is rather good. By leveling up you unlock different outfits for your character, allowing you to personalise him as you see fit. Anyone wishing to play as a female character may be slightly dissapointed as you can only play as a male character. You can however choose from three different body types, Light, medium and heavy. all with their own advantages and drawbacks. e.g Light characters can run very fast but can be killed in only a few hits, wheras the heavy characters take more damage, but move slower. There are also perks and abilities for each class, with the Medic being able to upgrade his healing abilities, the engineer can gain a sentry gun upgrade, the soldier can dispense more ammo to comrades and the operative can genrally become more sneaky. More weapons and attachments for said weapons can be unlocked through the completion of individual challenges, separate from the main game. Most of these challenges are fairly easy, and don't require a great deal of effort, allowing you to unlock all the weapons and attachments somewhat quickly. The game has a wide variety of weapons to choose from, allowing for a good variety of playstyles.

Sadly, the multiplayer is fairly dead. Whenever I try to search for a match, there's no one else playing. This means you're left with the single player mode. However, those familiar with Star Wars battlefront's 'instant action' feature, will feel right at home as the 'free play' mode allows you to jump into any mission of your choosing, and apply custom mutators to that mission. Unfortuntely, the AI is not the best feature of this game as it is very temperamental. Sometimes the friendly AI will be as stupid as a sack of hammers and at others it will be flawless, the same can be said for the enemy AI, sometimes it wrecks you and your team, sometimes it just sits back and takes whatever beating you're giving it.

In conclusion, the game is fairly solid but is held back by the lack of an active multiplayer scene, the temperamental AI and the clunky parkour.

reviewText:
Brink is a parkour, class based, FPS with story that let's you customize your weapons to your specifications.


The following classes description was taken from wiki:  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brink_%28video_game%29

1.  Soldiers: Soldiers are primarily concerned with destroying important objects with explosives. They are also in charge of resupplying their teammates with ammo. Soldiers can also throw damaging speciality grenades, such as molotov cocktails, flashbang, and plant satchel charges similar to C4. With the proper ability equipped and utilised (Scavenger), they are the only class that have access to a potentially unlimited supply of ammunition.

2.  Engineers: The Engineer is concerned primarily with building, repairing, and upgrading things on the battlefield. Engineers must also disarm enemy explosives planted by soldiers as well as enemy landmines. He can also upgrade his and his teammate's weapons to do more damage, upgrade teammates' body armour, and plant hidden landmines.

3.  Medics: Medics revive downed teammates and buff their teammates' health. They also have special health buffs they can dispense to their teammates, such as improving their teammates' metabolism (how fast they heal on the battlefield) or temporarily boosting their sprint speed. They are the only class that can buff their own health or self-resurrect themselves when downed.

4.  Operatives: Operatives are the spies of Brink. They can hack computers to complete certain Mission Objectives and can also disguise themselves as the enemy. They are the only class that can spot hidden landmines.


The game was pretty damn good, but by now the games online would probably be dead.  So beware when purchasing.  Everyone working as a team was fantastic and fun.  The parkour is exactly as it sounds.  You do a lot of jumping here and sliding there.  Think Titanfall if you've played that, but without the jetpacks.  Customization is cool in which you unlock certain attachments and upgrades for your weapons and how you characters look.  Similar to how Call of Duty does it, but Brink's user interface makes it look all pretty and the 3D models of weapons stands out.

Interesting, fun and well worth checking out.  It does have a story and simi-single player.  Drop in Drop out coop online, but chances are you'll be playing by yourself unless you have some friends willing to play with you.

reviewText:
I've previously owned this game before on PS3, so I decided to give the game another chance on PC.

Personally, I like the artstyle, its fairly unique and sets the game apart from other run of the mill shooters. Although it is what you'd expect, everything for the resistance is improvised and gritty, everything for the security forces is shiny, white and looks brand new, etc. The soundtrack is also decent, the main menu theme is currently stuck in my head as I write this review.

The gameplay is class based, the game requires a large degree of teamwork to accomplish any of the objectives, this isn't really a game where you can be the lone wolf and decimate everything in your path. Anyone familiar with games such as TF2 or star wars battlefront, will feel right at home with the gameplay. The only aspect of the gameplay I don't like is the parkour, its very jerky, sometimes unresponsive, and difficult to pull off in certain situations due to the 1st person view limiting your perspective of the surrounding environment, it feels like the parkour was an afterthought and was wedged in at the last minute in order to attract the Mirrors Edge crowd. However, I've found that parkour isn't particularly usefull in all the missions anyway, so the clunkyness isn't really a problem as I rarely used parkour to its full extent.

Character customisation is rather good. By leveling up you unlock different outfits for your character, allowing you to personalise him as you see fit. Anyone wishing to play as a female character may be slightly dissapointed as you can only play as a male character. You can however choose from three different body types, Light, medium and heavy. all with their own advantages and drawbacks. e.g Light characters can run very fast but can be killed in only a few hits, wheras the heavy characters take more damage, but move slower. There are also perks and abilities for each class, with the Medic being able to upgrade his healing abilities, the engineer can gain a sentry gun upgrade, the soldier can dispense more ammo to comrades and the operative can genrally become more sneaky. More weapons and attachments for said weapons can be unlocked through the completion of individual challenges, separate from the main game. Most of these challenges are fairly easy, and don't require a great deal of effort, allowing you to unlock all the weapons and attachments somewhat quickly. The game has a wide variety of weapons to choose from, allowing for a good variety of playstyles.

Sadly, the multiplayer is fairly dead. Whenever I try to search for a match, there's no one else playing. This means you're left with the single player mode. However, those familiar with Star Wars battlefront's 'instant action' feature, will feel right at home as the 'free play' mode allows you to jump into any mission of your choosing, and apply custom mutators to that mission. Unfortuntely, the AI is not the best feature of this game as it is very temperamental. Sometimes the friendly AI will be as stupid as a sack of hammers and at others it will be flawless, the same can be said for the enemy AI, sometimes it wrecks you and your team, sometimes it just sits back and takes whatever beating you're giving it.

In conclusion, the game is fairly solid but is held back by the lack of an active multiplayer scene, the temperamental AI and the clunky parkour.

reviewText:
I'm writing this as someone who'd enjoy this at its prime on the Xbox.
This game had a lot of desirable elements that hadn't been seen in a lot of other shooters at the time. Yet, it still felt like a condensed version of TF2 prior to the customization. But that made it interesting. The classes by name were there, but a lot of the elements mixed together in a clunky and sometimes enjoyable game.
Like the medic aspect, it could be paired with a spy-like ability and a scout-like speed. All good on there own, all pretty hard to work with when melded together.
Would I recommend this game? Hella. If only on sale and under $5. The game has a linear campaign that repeats in a multiplayer format, which means that multiplayer to this game was almost a requirement. Within a month of buying this game, the active players number was almost gone already, and it was a bot vs bot game, which was just a merciless frustration. Buy this game and bring friends, a lot of em'. Honestly, if this game were just introduced again on a different face, it'd probably do well. It's an experience, the guns, the characters, even the movement style. But the lack of players and clunky class unity, (among other things) rightfully brought it a quick demise. I'd love to see this go F2P, because it'd pull in a lot of players and revive the servers for a short while. It has a lot of good in it, but not enough interest to inspire a renovation worthy enough of bringing it back.

Buy it cheap, play with friends. Avoid bots.

reviewText:
Brink is an epic first person shooter that should not be missed by anyone. Ignore the other comments that people make about this, because this is a true masterpiece.

The combat in this game feels solid and the AIs are of a reasonable difficulty, and the three difficulty levels make the game accessible for all gamers. Getting kills feels very satisfying and rewarding in this game, and you can even see the XP roll in as you deal damage.

The gameplay in Brink is excellent and provides fun each time you play. The game is very clear with regards to the in-game objectives, as there is an 'objective wheel' which directs you towards each objective.

In addition, the graphics in Brink are very good for the time and have features such as anti-aliasing and aniostropic filtering. The graphics engine used in Brink is very well optimised for the PC, so the game will run on most modern PCs.

However, the primary objective can sometimes switch quickly and suddenly, which can make you a bit confused with where you need to be.

Overall, Brink is an outstanding game and deserves much more respect than it gets, so I am giving it an official grade of A*.

A game that had a lot of potential and completely failed to deliver.

The Good:
-Conceptually, it's very cool.  It was obviously designed from the ground up to be a different team FPS experience, and it had a lot of potential.
-The graphics are clean and stylized.

The Bad:
-A totally lackluster singleplayer experience.  No campaign worth mentioning, it's just multiplayer with bots.
-For all the talk of classes, roles, and cooperation, ultimately every class kind of feels the same in a firefight.
-When the community died, the game died.  It has no replay value if your friends aren't logging in.
-Controls are iffy.

Don't bother with it unless you have a sizeable group of friends who play.  Even then, try to convince them to get something else.  Maybe TF2, if you don't mind the hats.

This game is beyond the most strategic and action-packed arena game as of late. Indeed the characters are curiously modeled, but it's just Brink's unique graphics. No other arena game- save perhaps Halo Reach, has such a multitude of combinations to create a truly unique character.
I suppose there may not be anymore dedicated servers, I've never noticed a different between them and private hosted servers, which Brink has.
If you haven't bought the game; buy it. And if you own it, join the Brink universe again, get it back on it's feet.
Call of Duty has an impressive arsenal, sure, but there's absolutely no strategy involved, and I'm not certain as I've given up on that franchise, but as far as I'm concerned doesn't have character customizations, as with Brink, your character evolves as you progress.
And the combat, with some games it's too complex, or the game itself pratically fights for you, but with Brink you have inumerable ways to approach a firefight, with inumerable guns, and as a character with no equal.

reviewText:
For all that hipsters and cynics love to mock it, we owe a lot to Brink. It was Brink that set the benchmark for how shooters looked and played in the HD era. It was Brink that redefined the FPS as all-action blockbuster, while transforming multiplayer.

The premise is interesting, albeit faintly ridiculous. In the near future a new power – The Federation – rises in South America and its influence begins to spread across the world.  Federation forces attack a US orbital weapon and turn its weapons of mass destruction against the US, blasting half of the states back into the stone age and putting an end to North American dominance of the region.

Brink's one shining aspect is SMART (Smooth Movement Across Random Terrain). Using SMART, holding a single button lets you navigate up walls, over obstacles, and through the game world. Depending on your body size, you can do more or less with movement, but overall this finesse is fantastic. Nothing in Brink feels quite as good as sliding under gunfire into someone, taking them out with a shotgun.

Brink is by far the worst ♥♥♥♥ing game my friends have ever played!

7/10 A Masterpiece.

The character customization is less deep than I thought it would be, however Brink's gameplay is solid. Brink manages to deliver a shooter experience so fun, that I wouldn't hesitate to call it one of the best games of this year, if not the last decade. In a time of L.A. reviewText:
While it is easy to find a review or detailed information on a game such as this one, it is no doubt the best option to try out the game to get the 'feeling' of how it is. Brink being an FPS game, is slightly different than other FPS games in terms of the following facts:

2) Parkour. David Belle's parkour makes its (probably) second return in gaming world. Being able to move around the environment using parkour is great but you should be aware of the fact that only Light Body and Medium Body types get to do them, as oppose to the Heavy Body types. The trade off lies in which weapon you can carry based on the body type you choose.
3) Get it if you are tired of playing mediocre game like Call of Duty. :D

reviewText:
I'll be up front: BRINK's promises of extensive customization and a seamless singleplayer/multiplayer experience are just so much hype, thankfully only in very specific ways. The customization of the characters isn't as detailed and indepth as several on-hand video demos pre-release made it seem to be, and the Artifical Intelligence? They're useless on non-defense objectives for the most part, since offensive teams swarm too tightly and too furiously for your disorganized AI companions to be much help.

However, BRINK's encouragement of objective focus rather than kill focused teamwork and gameplay REALLY help to make the ONLINE experience a joy: Players are more likely to assist and work together to achieve a goal than in most other team and class focused games I've played. SMARTS works great, and will be 'stolen' for use in other games, I suspect.

My advice? Buy only if interested in the theme and style of the game.

reviewText: This was supposed to be a good game. An objective based team multiplayer FPS from the developers of Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory and Enemy Territory: Quake Wars? It sounds like it should be the next best thing in online FPS gaming, but sadly, this turned out to not be the case. The art direction and the free running mechanic is pretty much all there is that's good about this game. Poor gun mechanics, poor controls, poor optimization, a community that was nearly dead as soon as the game launched, poor server browser, and practically no post release support all helped in putting Brink into an early grave. Gamers buried this one alive while it still had life in it, because there was just no future hope for this title. Seeing how Splash Damage is now developing a new free to play FPS called Dirty Bomb, the chances of this going free to play are basically zero, so this game is as good as dead now.\n\nHere's hoping that Splash Damage has learned from their mistakes with Brink...

reviewText: Brink is one of the better squad-based FPSs to come out within the last year. The gunplay and character controls feel spot-on, and they're married with an elegant teamplay mechanic and fantastic graphic and audio design. Although the parkour is woefully underused by the players, mastery of this mechanic brings Brink up to one of my favorite shooters of all time. The parkour mechanic, like the Battlefield franchise's Destruction mechanic, will become genre-defining with time. Other shooters now feel incomplete without it.\n\nUnfortunately, there are some under-the-hood issues with matchmaking and high-end graphic settings. Brink is also a complete mess on the consoles. Despite these flaws, I still have more fun with Brink than I do with all other shooters save BFBC2.

reviewText:
This is a balanced role & objective-based fps. Gear & abilities unlock as you level, and it unlocks quickly. There are also training levels that unlock gear as well. You also unlocks fashions at the same time. Each of the roles have a specific advantage that support each other and the objective through buff and abilities (which is tweakable each level). You can semi-switch your role on the fly - you go to consoles your team controls. You can alo switch your weapon loadout the same way. The only thing you can't change is your build type (you have to quit the match, tweak, and then join a new match), which is related to the size of weapons you can hold, how quickly you move, and how agile you - which is related to whether you can parkour and to what extent.

There is no jump or run button in the game, it's just a movement button of sorts. You hold it down and you'll run, and based on your movement inputs it allows you to go under or over objects, or to climb up things. It also has tactical value because you can use it to not only manuever, but to also knock over your opponents and avoid fire. It's a very slick mechanic. Melee attacks aren't designed to kill, they're designed to knock opponents down so that you can do other stuff to them. Everything has a specific design, even grenades - it's all very well balanced. You don't immediately kill people when their health is exhausted, you incapacitate them, which gives their allies a chance to revive them. You have to specifically go out of your way to finish them off with another melee or expend some of your limited ammo and hope your allies are the appropriate role and are buffing you with ammo. When you are incapacitated you can either wait for an ally to try and heal you, and it'll show you where the nearest ally capable of healing is and whether they have the supplies to do so, or you can die and wait for the spawn timer which you can also see - giving you more tactical choices.

Each player has limited supplies of their buffs/abilities, but they're slowly regained. Everything is designed so that you have to rely on each other. This game really didn't catch on, as much as I wish it did. It's clear that it was thought out very well. Unfortunately no one plays it anymore, and I have a feeling it was a nonstarter on PC. I had a lot of fun with Brink.

I purchased the game for the 360 when it released - I had an injury to where playing it with the keyboard/mouse was nigh impossible. I got a couple hundred hours on the xbox and when I could use my hand normally I picked it up on the PC. At the time they had a notice that they 'now' had controller support, so I thought why stress out my hand I'll just use the controller, besides the PC always has more people to play with right? Not so. Well the controller support didn't, and still doesn't work and if you try to get it to work expect to put about 10-15 hours of messing around with it before you decide to go back to keyboard and mouse and hope that all that registry editing didn't break anything permanently, because it will break the game - expect to reinstall a couple of time trying to get the controller to work. So a note about the keyboard and mouse controls - this game was optimized for the use for a controller with it's movement options being tied to one button, but it doesn't have built-in controller support. So the keyboard controls are very simplistic. There are also more players on the console than on PC.

Brink has time trials, single player/co-op, and multiplayer - though the SP/co-op and multiplayer are a matter of semantics, playing against bots or players. The story is interesting and there are two different factions to play through with their stories, points of view, and ideas. Accomplishing or not accomplishing objectives fulfills one side or the others story affecting the ending of the match and what team advances in their storyline. All-in-all I'd recommend this game, it's fun, fast, and interesting, even with it's flaws. You might like it just for the fashion mini-game - each character you create comes with a different version for each faction that needs body type, heritage, tatoos/scarring, clothes, and armor all with a mix of colors and styles - and each different based on their faction. If you decide to jump in you should probably get a copy for all your friends unless you're willing to stay up to weird hours in the hopes to play with people you met on the forums - which is unlikely since the multplayer is dead. I remeber matchmaking with trying to get friends all in the same match being an issue, but I haven't played in a while, so I'm not sure if that was fixed. Either way it's still fun solo for at least one run through of each faction, which will be about ten hours of playtime.
